thread.section_title: Financial Review - Business, Finance and Investment News | afr.com
thread.title: Employment beats forecasts, supports RBA view of stabilisation
thread.title_full: Employment beats forecasts, supports RBA view of stabilisation | afr.com

author: Jacob Greber
title: Employment beats forecasts, supports RBA view of stabilisation
text:
The jobs market had its best six-month start to a year since 2008, boosting speculation the worst may be over. iStock Share on twitter by Jacob Greber The labour market has recorded its best six-month start to a year since 2008, delivering the Reserve Bank of Australia a rare dose of good news that suggests further official interest rate cuts are not needed.
Employment has grown by 120,700 people since December, helping keep a lid on increases in the jobless rate, which came in at 6 per cent in June, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
An improving jobs market – which has been bolstered by a solid rise in hours worked – suggested the lower dollar and record-low official interest rates were spurring growth in construction, education and tourism.
That was helping offset a fall in jobs in the mining states, expected by many economists to continue in coming months.
While the jobs data supported the view that the Reserve Bank's official interest rate cuts in February and May were gaining traction, many analysts pointed out that the newer jobs tended to be in low-wage and low-productivity sectors compared with the big-money mining jobs they had replaced.
As a result, the improvement was likely to deliver less of a boost to the federal government's coffers.
NSW led the nation in June, with 11,400 extra jobs, with Victoria and Queensland posting falls of 5500 and 1300 jobs respectively.
The improvement was reflected this week in a subtle shift in the Reserve Bank's language on the jobless rate, which it said on Tuesday was still high but no longer rising.
 Reserve Bank and Treasury economists expected the jobless rate to hit 6.5 per cent late next year, but the latest data had buoyed speculation that the worst may be over.
"The risk is that the unemployment rate peaks lower and sooner," said Commonwealth Bank analyst Gareth Aird, who predicted the Reserve Bank would not deliver any more rate cuts.
"Looking at the picture since the beginning of 2015, it's quite clear that conditions in the Australian labour market have been stable," he said.
Monthly jobs growth had averaged 20,000 which was slightly above the number required to keep the jobless rate flat, given the population was expanding. If that continued, most economists expected the rate to begin coming down.
"History shows that the RBA tends not to cut further when the unemployment rate is past its peak," said HSBC economist Paul Bloxham. "So, at the minimum, today's numbers are likely to reduce the chance of any near-term cut in the cash rate."
But not all were convinced.
"Today's data do not incorporate the impact of any shock being imparted by the developments in Europe and China ," said JPMorgan economist Ben Jarman.
"There are still some negative demand impulses to be digested. Of particular importance will be whether global turbulence hits activity in the non-mining economy."
The dollar, which hit a six-year low this week after the Chinese sharemarket meltdown and falling commodity prices, rose after the jobs data to about US74.62¢ from about US74.19¢.
Full-time employment jumped 24,500 and part-time work dropped 17,200.
